title: wtf is the point of chat restrict aside from preventing you from coordinating and cause frustration?
body:
Like wtf does it accomplish? It just the game saying you can't talk and watch all your garbo team mates make horrible mistakes while you have to sit there and accept the loss without question.

What sucks is the fact that when you try to help these brain dead kids play better they cry and call it toxic when in reality you are telling them the harsh truth that they suck dick and need to get their act together. Yet this game wants to please its player base and so it limits freedom of expression for money. 

Which makes it even more frustrating because now you are sitting there losing games because you got paired with trash teammates and then you get punished for criticizing their actions. This is why this game needs to die.

Inb4 haters/trolls/goodie goodie <<REMOVED BY MODERATION>>

replies.body:
Hey Ichibiri,

I have removed offensive portions of your post. While it's understandable to be frustrated, it's important to remember that there are right and wrong ways to express that frustration.

~ Ulanopo.

Nobody has to see the CRed brat run their mouth endlessly, which is a _massive_ benefit to coordination.

I am sure the CRed brat always thinks it has something important to say, thus the CR.

If someone cant use chat without flaming their team, they need to be removed from the game permanently. It is a warning to them to shape up their behavior.

Actually, I think in roughly 70% of the matches I play, most of my teammates tend to work well both individually and blend into concerted action in the later stages of the game, often without someone taking a leadership role.

Although, it should also be said that _you get matched with players of similar skill level_, so, if you're getting "garbo teammates", that probably means that you're likely performing poorly yourself. And, I mean that with all due respect, but you may probably take it as an insult anyway.

> Half the LoL population is in silver/bronze....Theres a good reason for that. Most people get stuck with bads and are FORCED to take the loss,

If half of the population are in Bronze/Silver Tiers, then odds are, they're just at that skill level. They'll likely grow out into Gold or higher-tier skill levels over time, but ultimately (and I speak only of Solo/Duo Queue here), their rank relies on their own personal skill, not that of other players.

At least, that's just the way I see it. I could be wrong, and I welcome anyone with the proper information to correct me on it, but, yeah.

> their(sic) is no repercussions for those trash players.

Because players shouldn't be punished for not being good at the game.

---

> I like how you try to play your words off as civilized and still try and get in some jabs at me. Typical trash pretending to be goodie because you know mods are watching.

I don't really care whether or not the mods are watching. I just try to be as tactful and respectful as possible while phrasing things. If I cross a line, I'll accept it when they step in to admonish me. If you take offence - well, I already told you, I mean it with respect. What you take away from it is your own.

But, I also effectively made a point.

To quote your main post:

> What sucks is the fact that when you try to help these brain dead kids play better they cry and call it toxic when in reality you are telling them the harsh truth that they suck dick and need to get their act together.

You are _all for_ telling players the "harsh truth" that they suck at the game, that they're bad, etc., but the moment it's implied that _you yourself may be unskilled_, you take it as an insult regardless of how well it's phrased. That shows two things:

1. Nobody likes being called unskilled.
2. You are, unfortunately, hypocritical.

---

> Anyways you replying to every one of my posts, I take it I struck a nerve in you because you know deep down its the truth.

What is it that you're calling the truth, exactly? That all matches require one person to be a leader? That Riot's trying to quash your freedom of speech? That players with differing playstyles should be considered "breaking the rules"? Or, was there something I missed?

Say what you will, but it's pretty hard to strike one of my nerves. It takes something obscenely irrational or plain ignorant to do that, and even then I wouldn't bother responding. Plus, there's no harm in a little rapid-fire response if I can suitably answer/respond to your questions/statements, no?

> But I don't want to bicker with idiots. This game nor the people in it will change. Hope you and this game die

Call me an idiot all you like, doesn't really make it true, now does it?

As for change - well, if they don't want to change, they won't. You can't force them to. It sucks, but them's the 8r8ks.

And, hoping for the game to die is one thing, but hoping for _me_ to die? That's way over the line.

well first off... giving someone advice/making calls is a good thing. thinking that they have to do as you say or trying to force them to do as you say is not good anymore. its a rulebreak.

i think the point of chatrestrictions is at first maybe trying to teach you that you dont need the chat that much. you dont even need pings. they are just nice tools to help you out.
and 2.nd i think CR also is supposed to be like a gentle slap in your face saying "HEY! if you dont stop, you will be permabanned soon". 

i myself think the 25 games cr should be replaced by a 24 or 48 hour ban.

Not obeying the person flaming them isn't against the rules, by the way. People having differing playstyles is also not against the rules.

I've seen people split push relentlessly even though we really needed them in teamfights - sometimes even as non-split-push Champions. Pretty often it ended detrimentally, other times it panned out. Sometimes they even actually joined in teamfights and we won or lost as a team.

Their decisions differing from yours does not mean they're breaking the rules. They want to win just as much as you, if not more, they just have different visions of how to do so.

If you think this game needs to die, then I'm so greatly elated to tell you _that ain't happening soon!_ Buckle up, 'cause I imagine League's gonna be around for a good long while.
If you get to the point that you got Chat Restricted, I highly doubt you have much "coordinating" that anyone on your team would respect to follow anyway.

As for strategic communication, I can't comment much since I've never had a restriction and don't really know how much it restricts you by. But I'd have to assume that, between pings and a few sentences, you'll be able to call the shots you need.

Comic isn't relevant. He is saying he would like freedom to say what he wants, Riot is explicitly not giving him that freedom because they do not condone it.

To argue otherwise is to misinterpret the OP and the comic. Although the comic mentions you can say what you want on internet forums, that is different from what the OP is expressing.

The comic _is_ relevant, because it explains what Freedom of Speech is and what it isn't. Riot can't give or withhold his freedom of speech, because they aren't the government - and the government isn't arresting the OP, so, he still has his freedom of speech intact.

> To argue otherwise is to misinterpret the OP and the comic.

What's there to misinterpret from either?

Quote from OP:

> I'd rather have freedom of speech

He's mistaking freedom of speech for freedom of consequence.

Transcript from the comic:

> Public Service Announcement:
> The **Right to Free Speech** means the government can't arrest you for what you say.
>
> It doesn't mean that anyone else has to listen to your bullshit, or host you while you share it.
>
> The 1st Amendment doesn't shield you from criticism or consequences.
>
> If you're yelled at, boycotted, have your show cancelled, or get banned from an internet community, your free speech rights aren't being violated.
>
> It's just that the people listening think you're an asshole,
>
> And they're showing you the door.

Pretty cut-and-dry, no?

"Freedom of speech means you can't be arrested for what you say, but that doesn't mean anyone else has to put up with it."

---

> Although the comic mentions you can say what you want on internet forums,

No, it doesn't. Read it again:

> If you're yelled at, boycotted, have your show cancelled, or _**get banned from an internet community**_, your free speech rights aren't being violated.

It mentions that your rights to free speech don't protect you from being given the boot from an internet community, like this one.

If anyone's misinterpreting the comic, unfortunately, that'd be you.

---

> that is different from what the OP is expressing.

The OP is expressing that he wants to bad-mouth, shit-talk, and spew filth at anyone without consequences. There's nothing that can safeguard him from the consequences. The comic is, again, relevant.

Right.

But the OP is not saying He wants the US Government to give him freedom of speech.
The OP is saying he wants RIOT to give him freedom of speech. 

And that makes the comic moot. The answer is NO Riot does not give freedom of speech. Simple as that. But to say they do but make their own rules or they don't have to is not doing anything.

The comic literally says that freedom of speech has ONLY to do with the government, not corporations... It's like if you go into work one day and call your female or black co-workers super derogatory names and you KNOW that's against corporate policy. You used your freedom to say what you wanted, but you broke corporate's rules while doing so, which means they have every right to fire you (consequence) for your actions (freedom of speech). All of us agree to TOS when we sign up to play. Those are our corporate guidelines. You break them, Riot has more than enough right to fire you.

But the OP WANTS free speech from RIOT in the GAME they 'Govern.'

He is not asking for free speech in life. He is asking for in game free speech, which Riot has the power to give or restrict. Riot could easily change the ToS if they wanted is all I am saying, so using that comic is just people ignoring the issue.

And to that point. The ToS also probably say you may get offended, we can't control all the content, this is an online game. But then they can get offended and get extra treatment.

And you could easily ask your boss to give you free speech for calling out your co-workers. That doesn't mean they will because you've proven yourself unworthy of that free speech in public by being rude as all fuck. You know what it comes down to? Human decency. Common sense. The ability to actually empathize. Riot doesn't have to offer people like OP anything, because if they reward that behavior, they open themselves to lawsuits and losing business. If you have nothing nice to say, or if you don't understand the difference between trash talk and flaming if you must speak, you don't need to play this game. Period.

And I never said give him free speech.

I have been arguing for months, Riot should take away ALL speech in the game. Or at least for people who request it. Bans for speech are bs, when they can give a permanant mute/squelch.

My only point here is, don't post a stupid comic or one line that isn't relevant. You aren't clever for doing so.

> But the OP is not saying He wants the US Government to give him freedom of speech.
> The OP is saying he wants RIOT to give him freedom of speech.

> And that makes the comic moot.

No? First of all, that he's asking for the wrong thing from the wrong people doesn't make the comic (which talks about the _very thing he's asking for_) moot. It's not debatable - he's talking about freedom of speech (which he has) as though it encompasses freedom of consequence (which it doesn't), and the comic says _just that_.

Quotes from the OP:

> If I had freedom of speech then I wouldn't have to worry about the consequences of speaking my mind. Your logic is flawed...

Which, again, _the comic literally says that what OP thinks is not the case._

> The Right to Free Speech means the government can't arrest you for what you say.
> 
> It doesn't mean that anyone else has to listen to your bullshit, or host you while you share it.
> 
> _The 1st Amendment doesn't shield you from criticism or **consequences.**_

I say once again, for the final time: _**The comic is relevant.**_

---

> The answer is NO Riot does not give freedom of speech. Simple as that. 

I already said something along those lines. To quote:

> Riot can't give or withhold his freedom of speech, because they aren't the government...

Which, that you said it as well only cripples your argument, because since Riot isn't the government, they cannot _give_ you the right to free speech, _or take it away_. **_Your freedom to say what you want without government intervention is not harmed, violated, or in any way breached by Riot's actions._**

> But to say they do but make their own rules or they don't have to is not doing anything.

Believe what you want. He clearly wants freedom speech in LOL from RIOT.

Twist words to fit you comic. And yes, the comic mentions you can have consequences online, etc. But his point is he wishes RIOT would let him say what he wants.

wish all he wants, that's not happening...

And that is fine with me. (although I do have some wishes).

My point is just don't post a comic or a one-liner thinking you are clever when it isn't pertinent to what is being asked. He never shouted this is America, or the government gave me speech. He was asking Riot for speech.
Fantastic. I will do that when on computer. The question is, what is the phone equivalent?
IDK, I don't use the mobile app but, I am guess it syncs with your profile or there is a settings menu somewhere within the app

Common misconception. Freedom of speech does not protect you from the consequences of your actions. You're more than welcome to call a random business and tell them there's a bomb that's going to blow the place up. It doesn't mean you won't be arrested for making terroristic threats or inciting a panic. Freedom of Speech under law is the right to speak your beliefs without the GOVERNMENT censoring or imprisoning you for voicing said belief. It doesn't mean you can just say whatever you want and private citizens need to swallow it. And it doesn't free you of responsibility if whatever you say (like the aforementioned bomb threat) has some sort of punishment involved.

Fact is, when you play this game, you have to click "yes" to an agreement that states (in part, and paraphrased for simplicity) that you will not harass, insult, or be negative towards other players, and if you are, Riot can punish you for it. You agree by clicking yes. If you are then negative to other players, you've broken your agreement and will be punished. You shouldn't be surprised about it. You said you wouldn't do it. You agreed that Riot had the right to punish you if you did. Then you did it. Getting punished for it shouldn't be a surprise at that point. It should be expected.

Speech described in your sense is absolutely different from speech of insulting someone. And you would have to stretch it to say a threat to someone is the same, you can stretch it but it is a stretch.

Riot also (I assume only) has clauses that say This is an online game, we can't control all the content, make sure you are ok with that before proceeding. So if a few words deeply and truly hurt you, you probably weren't prepared to be online in the first place.

> Riot also (I assume only) has clauses that say This is an online game, we can't control all the content, make sure you are ok with that before proceeding.

That roughly means that there is stuff that players are allowed to do/say that may not be palatable to others. Cursing, for example. Some people may not be okay with cursing, but Riot can't (and won't) police it if it's just omnidirectional barks that do nobody any harm.

What it doesn't mean, though, is this:

> So if a few words deeply and truly hurt you, you probably weren't prepared to be online in the first place.

This statement is completely ignorant. There is no "being prepared" to being online, period, and to say that someone shouldn't be online simply because they could be affected by words is beyond stupid. The internet isn't some horrific warzone that you need months of mental preparation just to dive into.

That's like saying "if you can't take a punch to the face, then you're probably not prepared to go outside". A lot of people will not generally be able to do that, and it's some inane, ill-thought prerequisite that has no bearing at all on whatever activity someone's outside to be doing.

If I say xyz xyz xyz directed to NO ONE, is it still harmful? Because obviously Riot would say yes? You would say yes? How is that ANY different from any curse word?
Riot is simply choosing to police some things above and beyond what normal life polices.

If you are scared of snakes, would you go to a herpetarium known for snakes? In normal circumstances, NO you would not. Likewise, if you are afraid a bad word is going to hurt your feelings or offend you, you shouldn't put yourself in those situations. 
I understand Riot policing words. But you can't just let users off the hook every instance. It is a two way street, they also know what they are potentially signing up for, even if that is not what Riot wants to be known as or what is common.

There's been a fair handful of people in previous boards posts on PB that claimed they were punished for cursing. Several people have clarified that you can't be punished for cursing as long as you A. Do not direct it harmfully at anyone, and B. Do not spam it needlessly.

I can say "fuck", "shit", "damn", "son of a bitch", etc. 'til the cows come home in a match, as long as I'm not saying things like "fuck you", "you piece of shit", "you are the worst damn player I've ever seen", "you're a son of a bitch", etc.

Which is my point:

> That roughly means that there is stuff that players are allowed to do/say that may not be palatable to others. Cursing, for example.

Some people may not like cursing, for various reasons. Some folks are perfectly fine with cursing, so long as it isn't in excess, and then there are people who are A-O-K with people using "fuck" between every word, using it as an article, a punctuation mark, and several other grammatical tools.

And Riot understands that they can't prevent cursing, so they won't. They can't even really prevent harassment or abuse, either, but - as it's against the rules, they're more than willing to cut it down wherever it crops up.

Also, your analogy is strange. "xyz" has no ascribed meaning to it, but even still, as long as you don't direct it spitefully at anyone or spam it, you're generally free to use it.

Unless, of course, you're using "xyz" as analogous to hate speech - in which case, regardless of whether or not you direct it at anyone, it is still extremely harmful and extremely toxic. Hate speech is its own category because it's derogatory speech used to single out and abuse, deride, and dehumanize people of various lifestyles or ethnicities. There is no excuse to use it.

---

> If you are scared of snakes, would you go to a herpetarium known for snakes? In normal circumstances, NO you would not. Likewise, if you are afraid a bad word is going to hurt your feelings or offend you, you shouldn't put yourself in those situations.

Let me put it to you this way - my analogy of "you shouldn't go outside if you can't take a punch to the face" was said because in general, both the real world and League of Legends have rules. People and players of both are expected to abide by those rules.

Some people can take a mean hit. Some players are generally unaffected by words. Some people can't suffer a punch, just like some players may be affected by other peoples' words. However, it is a general rule that you shouldn't have to deal with either.

You're not allowed to go out on the streets throwing suckerpunches at folks, just like you aren't allowed to go into the Rift and start harassing and berating people.

This isn't about "fear", this isn't about "people's feelings", this is about _**the rules we're supposed to follow**_.

If you can't follow the rules, then get out. Simple as that.

---

> I understand Riot policing words. But you can't just let users off the hook every instance.

They're not, and they don't. Riot has a set of rules that all players must abide by. Those that you say get "let off the hook" are people who are actually following the rules. The people getting punished are breaking the rules.

> It is a two way street, they also know what they are potentially signing up for, even if that is not what Riot wants to be known as or what is common.

The reputation League has for having a toxic community is one of two things they know they're signing up for. The rules create the expectation that toxic players get punished. Players are signing up for a community that may not be the best, but one that Riot is actively weeding out for bad players.

Replace xyz with K.. except directed at no one. just used to vent frustration. I certainly wouldn't call it hate speech.

one of the rules of most online games is.. 'you may see or hear things that are intended for older audiences/may offend you. are you ok with that.'
That is one of the rules too. Yes, Riot has rules to try to limit it. But they agreed to it, and in this case it isn't a big deal. But if someone were to sue Riot for committing suicide, I am sure that rule would magically pop up as intended protection.
I will go outside tomorrow. Go to the hospital. See someone smoke a cigarette and get that nasty smoke in my eyes. The rule says no smoking. But no one is going to police it, and I will get over it because it literally does not affect my life (even though it does).

I think we are getting into unallowed discussion territory though. And we won't make any progress either way.

Whether or not it's allowed is certainly debatable, since, while slightly off-topic, it still pertains (for the most part) to the original subject, and it is still appropriate for the PB boards.

But, I will leave the conversation with two things:

1. Telling people to kill themselves _ANYWHERE_ is not allowed, and it is, indeed, hate speech. You are telling someone, for no real reason, to kill themselves. And if I recall, if you tell someone to kill themselves, and they _do_, you are held accountable as a murderer.
2. The "you may see or hear things that are intended for older audiences/may offend you. are you ok with that." thing was already explained. What you followed it with was also irrelevant, because _suggestions of self-harm are against the rules, and Riot deals with those people appropriately._

But again, saying Kill to no one in particular. but to vent frustration. Even if it says yourself, not directed at anyone. It still wouldn't be allowed.

If people are reporting you for criticizing their play, then maybe you should look at it a different way. They are in fact criticizing your ability to offer advice. You should learn how to offer advice without alienating your audience.

I am offended that you use "suck dick" negatively! Not only is it fun, it brings pleasure to another...

   That aside, you can offer constructive criticism but, as you are free to do so, they are free to ignore it. You need not harass someone all game, as they likely are not listening nor has that ever made someone play better. In fact, that is likely to tilt them and make it worse.
   The chat restrict is a slap on the wrists to enlighten you that the _community_ deems your behavior unacceptable.

I've never had a punishment, but I think it could be interesting to play with the restrictions active to see if I even notice having it. (And no,  I have no desire to actively sabotage my account just to experiment with the ban system)

The Chat Restriction is there to serve as a heads-up that your behavior towards other players isn't tolerable, and also to show you that you don't need a lot in the way of using the chat pane to communicate properly.

Judging by your choice of words in this post, I'm going to guess that you think you're a leader when in fact you're just a domineering elitist who doesn't care to show restraint or respect.

You can tell a player they're performing poorly without being needlessly crass or dickish about it. But, if you keep thinking that all your teammates are "brain dead kids", then odds are you're just going to keep spewing filth and hate that you call "shot calling" and get yourself banned.
Kid is clearly trolling.
I believe the point is to restrict your chat.
You can still communicate effectively while in a chat restriction, and ping others too. With less typing, you can also more easily observe good and bad chat.
